VOL. X.X.XI, No. 7

LOYOLA MAY PROVE
HARD TEST FOR JAYS
Byrne Is Expected to Trouble Hopkins
Linemen
COFALL EXPECTS TO WIN
Loyola Will Try to Avenge 87-0 Defeat
of 1924

What promises to be one of the
most closely fought games of the
Year at Homewood will be played
tomorrow,
when Hopkins meets
the
Loyola football team. Last
season the teams did not meet,
but this year they clash
'again.
Times have
changed, however,
and it is assured that there will
be no repetition of the 1924 encounter, when the honie- boys
slaughtered Loyola 87-0.
"NlY team will be in topnotch
Condition, and if we should be defeated, which we certainly shall
not, we will have no alibis -co
offer," says Coach Stanley Cofall.
Cofall has apparently developed
an extremely capable aggregation.
Form Reversed

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 22, 1926
GLENN HUNTER IS
PLAYSHOP GUEST
Mr. Glenn Hunter and Miss
Helen Gahagan, co-stars in
Mr. John Van Druton's play,
Young Woodley, which is
playing this week at Ford's,
and the other members of the
cast, were guests at a tea given
by the Homewood Playshop
Tuesday afternoon.
They
were introduced by Mr. John
E. Uhler, president of the
Playshop. Mr. Hunter and
Miss Gahagan were asked to
speak, and both took seats on
the stage to talk together to
their enthusiastic audience.
After a few moments of informal chatting, however, they
asked to have the orchestra
play. Singing and dancing
were prominent features of
the program. Tea was poured
by Mrs. Edwin Greenlaw.

Track Meet Added
To Frosh-Soph Sports
A track meet has been added to
the list of freshman-sophomore
clashes this year. Heretofore the
yearlings have had the opportunity of humiliating their tormentors on the gridiron and the diamond but interclass track is somewhat of a novelty. The meet will
be held around the middle of November.
Committees consisting. of Robey, Scheibel and Chalk for the
sophomores and Beewkes for the
freshmen have been appointed to
handle the teams. Plans are already under way. Both squads
will practice with the varsity under the coaching of "Ridge" Edwards.

FALL LACROSSE PRACTICE
BEGUN BY JAY STICK
WIELDERS
Thirty
Men
Report to
Captain
Robinson At Organization
Meeting Monday

MEETING AT LYRIC TODAY

Banquet Will Conclude
Anniversary Program
Tomorrow Night

Stiff Schedule

The fall practice, Captain Robinson explained, is primarily to
develop stickwork. Stickwork has
always carried the Black and Blue
to victory, and it is to stickwork
that Jays owe their fame and reputation. It was also announced
that the team will not play any
lacrosse clubs for two reasons, because the Jays get no credit if
they should down any club, while
on the other hand if some small
club should trounce Hopkins, the
Jays would be hurt considerably
and the club would get quite a
reputation. The Jays will not play
the Alumni for the same reason.
A very difficult schedule has
been outlined for the squad. The
foremost contenders for their
crown will be Army, Navy, Yale
and Maryland. Although Yale
has not a very strong team, it is
quite experienced with all kinds
of stick wielding, and through
this, the Bulldog downed Maryland's strong team several years
ago.

FIFTIETH ANNIVERSARY
CEREMONIES OPENED BY
D.D.K. SMOKER AT DORMS
Fifty Attend Tenth Year
Celebration of
Society

Only thirty men reported at the
organization meeting of the lacrosse team last Monday.. The
poor showing, Captain Robinson
thinks, is due to the fact that there
were other activity meetings on
the same day, and not to any lack
of lacrosse candidates. However
that may be, Robinson urged that
many more men come out, as
there were excellent opportunities
for all who wished to try out.

In the beginning of the year the
tearn appeared rather weak, defeating the weak Tank School
eleven in their game by only 7-0;
and then dropping the next two
c
ontests, one to Schuylkill by a
score of 12-2, and the next to William and Marv, 19-0.
During the last two weeks, however, there has been ‘a complete
reversal of form, and the Evergreens arrive here tomorrow fresh
from last Saturday's
28-0 victory
over Washington
College.

DR. GOODNOW

PRICE,5 CENTS

President Frank J. Goodnow,
Prominent Figure in Fiftieth
Anniversary Program

RIFLE TEAM COMPLETES
TENTATIVE SCHEDULE
FOR COMING SEASON
Four

Shoulder-to-Shoulder Matches
Scheduled; Torres' Absence
Hurts Team Chances

Celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Johns Hopkins University began last night when Omicron
Delta Kappa, honorary fraternity,
held a smoker at the Alumni Memorial Dormitory. The entertainment, commemorating the tenth anniversary of the society's founding
at Hopkins was attended by about
fifty members. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., acted as toastmaster and
I. EVans Rodgers entertained with
songs and jokes.
A meeting ,at the Lyric Theatre
this 'morning was the first important event of the anniversary program. Dr. Andrew Balfour, Director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Science, was the
principal speaker. Introductory remarks were made by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland and
Dr. William H. Welch.
Many of the various departments
of the University have planned conferences. for this afternoon and
dinners this evening. The physics
department has arranged a dinner
at the -Baltimore Country Club at
Roland Park, and members of the
class of 1891 will be the guests of
Mr. Alfred J. Shriver, prominent
local lawyer. Members of the biology, political economy and history
departments have also planned special entertainments and meetings
for this afternoon.

With the announcement of a
tentative schedule for the coming
year and the organization of the
rifle club, the rifle team is getting
under way.
The sch'edule . so far includes
twenty-five matches, eleven less
than last year; but this is by no
means complete.
Two new opponents have been
added thus far, Washington College and the formidable Navy
team, that Hopkins will meet
shoulder to shoulder on the same
range.
The weak point in the schedule
is the scarcity of shoulder to
shoulder matches, where the opposing teams meet on a the same
range. Only four have been

"THERE IS NONE SO BLIND"
After months of careful planning, the Half Century Celebration is now at its height. Hundreds of alumni, from all parts
of the country, and many other scholars of note are assembled in
what promises to be one of the most significant gatherings of its
kind ever held. The NEWS-LETTER wishes to add its welcome
to those already more formally expressed.
From a purely Hopkins point of view, the Half Century
Celebration is not only the most important event of the year;
it is the most important in many years, perhaps the greatest since
the inauguration of President Gilman. Viewed in this light, the
apathy which seems to prevail is little short of shocking. It would
be the most natural thing in the world to call this attitude indifference. But to do justice to the undergraduates, and we naturally include ourselves in that term, we do not think that is
the true reason.
The real cause is blindness. No student with any claim to intelligence will deny that the event is important. The trouble is
that it cannot be seen in its true perspective. Twenty years from
now undergraduates, if there be any, will look back on it with
considerable awe and no less regret. At present the everyday
affairs on the campus—sports, publications, and the hysteria of
the open week of fraternity rushing—all claim their share of attention; and leave the Half Century Celebration as an indistinct
unreality, too big to be grasped at once.
The first meeting has already been held; we hope that a fair
number of undergraduates attended. During the remainder of the
time, every student would do well to drop his routine activities,
or even neglect an assignment or two; and attend any phase of
the Celebration which is open to him. If in sonic cases that is
impossible they can read about it.

DISGUST NOT REQUIRED
There is, as anyone who takes the trouble may observe, a
column in the NEWS-LETTER known as the "Mailbag," composed
of letters addressed, as a manner of form and courtesy, to the
editor. Using the numbers of the NEWS-LETTER which have appeared this year as evidence, it would be equally correct to assume
that no one may submit a letter unless he is disgusted at something. The object of his wrath makes no difference: it may
range from the exhorbitant cost of drinking cups to the organization and administration of the whole University.
In this last assertion, however, circumstantial evidence proves
its inadequacy. A sour frame of mind is in no way frowned
upon, but it is by no means essential. We see a future for the
"Mailbag" if it is used sensibly. Since Hopkins is a universit5‘,
itiS safe to assume that there is some intellectual life among the
undergraduates. They must have views on literature, art, or
world affairs; if the views are conflicting, so much the better.
Why not make the letter column a forum as well as a complaint
column ?

Captain-elect Torres, who last
year won the marksmanship cup,
has not returned to the University
and his absence will be keenly
felt. This also necessitates the
election of a captain, which will

The tentative schedule is as follows:
December 4—Princeton, Denison.
December 11—Connecticut Aggies,
West Virginia, Gettysburg.
December 18—Vermont, Syracuse,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
January 8—U. of Porto Rico, North
Carolina State.
- January 15—Western Maryland,
Carnegie Tech.
February 5—Delaware, Washington
College.
February 12—Open, I. R. A.
February 19—I. R. A., Gettysburg
(shoulder match).
February 26-1. R. A., Maryland
(shoulder match).
March 5—I. R. A., Navy (shoulder
match).
March 12—I. R. A., Georgetown
(shoulder match).
March 19—Columbia, Illinois.

FALL LACROSSE PRACTICE
STARTED
(Continuedfrom Page I, Column 3)

good prospects for outhomes.
Liebensperger and Biddison, veteran defense men, are back, with
Mallonee showing some skill at
wing defense. There is a probability that Morrell, a veteran defense man, will play again this
year despite his being a graduate
student. Finn, who displayed remarkable skill in last year's Alumni game, is back again for goal,
with a possibility of Ferlaino's
playing in the non-league games.
Equipment was given out last
Tuesday and practice started the
same day. Robinson did not start
his Jays at strenuous practice the
first day as he did not want them
to get stiff at the beginning of the
fall practice season.

NOTICES
ALUMNUS!
If you want to keep up with
the University undergraduate
happenings, subscribe to the
NEWS-LETTER. It is the official campus publication. Write
to the Circulation Manager!
SOPHOMORES
All members of the sophomore
class are requested to obtain and
read copies of the newly drawnup class constitution from any
member of the Constitution Committee. Those on the committee
are R. Burnett, R. Wood, G. Hershey and S. V. Chapman.
LACROSSE
Lacrosse practice has been
called for Tuesday, Wednesday
and Friday afternoons.
CORRECTION
The correct date of the First
Cotillon, as announced by the
Cotillon Club, will be November
13, instead of November 30. The
News-Letter regrets the error of
its previous announcement.

A SURE FIRE EXTINGUISHER
AND A GOOD INSECTICIDE

Dear Sir:
This is the first time in two and
a half years of residence at Hopkins that I have felt the desire to
write to the NEWS-LETTER. It will
Probably be the last, so I beg you
to publish this humble epistle.
First, I want to state that I have
verY little appreciation of the fine
arts; my education in that line has
been sadly neglected: Second, I do
not care to oppose any efforts on
the part
of the person or persons
who may be trying to beautify the
campus.
But-----my ideas of aesthetics are
very much distorted by the construction
of a cinder path across
the upper quadrangle. I can't understand how a carload of. burnt
coal - enhances the appearance of a
Plot of grass, even though the burnt
coal is arranged in a temporarily
neat way. So much for the aesthetic side.
When the path is completed,- it
will be seldom used. Very few peoPle enjoy walking on them, and to
inY mind for good reasons. The
cinders dirty your shoes, blow in
your eyes, and add to the trouble
of walking. If the path is not run
straight from the West entrance of
the
Chemistry Laboratory to the
flimsy
wooden steps which facilitate one's descent to the level of
the Engineering Buildings, its function as a path will be hopeless.
Most college students have heard
that a straight line is the shortest
distance between two points, and
they always
have this idea in mind
when walking.
May I ask how the work on the
Path has gone
this far (half-way)
fl€1 escaped the notice of your edi- 1
torial
writers? I was very much
disappointed not to find an article
about it in to-day's NEWS-LETTER,
fact, that is why I took my pen
hand, etc. Why not appoint a
ccinunittee and have an investiga
tion? It is quite the thing these
Clays.
Yours very truly,
PETER F. CONROY, JR.
A MORE TIMELY ANSWER
To the
Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.

Dear Sir

Noticing the above, I perceive
that while the writer has lots of
faults to find,
he has few suggestions to give. Investigation has
already begun concerning the unsIghtly cinder path across
the quadrangle
It has been suggested to
the
powers in charge that a little
.-1°neY
1-1
spent on putting down an
inlaid,
flagstone walk would save
the
beautiful appearance of the upPer quadrangle
and likewise serve
as
a practical means of transportation.

story of the modern oscillograph is synonymous with the story of Joseph Willard
Legg, E. E. '16.
Legg's novel experiment was accomplished by a form of remote control rigged
up for the college laboratory's oscillograph.
Soon the Westinghouse Company ordered
one of his controls. And it was natural that
Legg should follow his device to East Pittsburgh the next autumn, after he graduated.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 22, 1926

4
FROSH-SOPH DEBATE SET
FOR DECEMBER 2
Dr. French Will Pick Teams on Next
Wednesday and Thursday

"Resolved: That the non-athletic
activities of the American college
constitute an unwise use of the students' time" will be the subject of
the Freshman-Sophomore debate, to
be held at the Assembly, December 2.
Try-outs for the teams of the
respective classes will be held next
Wednesday and Thursday, October
27 and 28, in room 112, Gilman
Hall, at 12:20 P. AI. The frosh
will meet on Wednesday and the
sophs on Thursday.
Each candidate should prepare a
three-minute talk on the above subject. The teams will be chosen by
Dr. French.

Seniors to Meet
Concerning Election

Carl J. Doederlein

As only fifty-five of the one
hundred and twenty-four graduating seniors voted in the recent election a quorum was not obtained. A
meeting will be held Tuesday to
straighten out the question. Either
the constitution will have to
be changed to make the election
valid, or a re-election will be necessary.

VOL. X.X.XI, No. 7

LOYOLA MAY PROVE
HARD TEST FOR JAYS
Byrne Is Expected to Trouble Hopkins
Linemen
COFALL EXPECTS TO WIN
Loyola Will Try to Avenge 87-0 Defeat
of 1924

What promises to be one of the
most closely fought games of the
Year at Homewood will be played
tomorrow,
when Hopkins meets
the
Loyola football team. Last
season the teams did not meet,
but this year they clash
'again.
Times have
changed, however,
and it is assured that there will
be no repetition of the 1924 encounter, when the honie- boys
slaughtered Loyola 87-0.
"NlY team will be in topnotch
Condition, and if we should be defeated, which we certainly shall
not, we will have no alibis -co
offer," says Coach Stanley Cofall.
Cofall has apparently developed
an extremely capable aggregation.
Form Reversed

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 22, 1926
GLENN HUNTER IS
PLAYSHOP GUEST
Mr. Glenn Hunter and Miss
Helen Gahagan, co-stars in
Mr. John Van Druton's play,
Young Woodley, which is
playing this week at Ford's,
and the other members of the
cast, were guests at a tea given
by the Homewood Playshop
Tuesday afternoon.
They
were introduced by Mr. John
E. Uhler, president of the
Playshop. Mr. Hunter and
Miss Gahagan were asked to
speak, and both took seats on
the stage to talk together to
their enthusiastic audience.
After a few moments of informal chatting, however, they
asked to have the orchestra
play. Singing and dancing
were prominent features of
the program. Tea was poured
by Mrs. Edwin Greenlaw.

Track Meet Added
To Frosh-Soph Sports
A track meet has been added to
the list of freshman-sophomore
clashes this year. Heretofore the
yearlings have had the opportunity of humiliating their tormentors on the gridiron and the diamond but interclass track is somewhat of a novelty. The meet will
be held around the middle of November.
Committees consisting. of Robey, Scheibel and Chalk for the
sophomores and Beewkes for the
freshmen have been appointed to
handle the teams. Plans are already under way. Both squads
will practice with the varsity under the coaching of "Ridge" Edwards.

FALL LACROSSE PRACTICE
BEGUN BY JAY STICK
WIELDERS
Thirty
Men
Report to
Captain
Robinson At Organization
Meeting Monday

MEETING AT LYRIC TODAY

Banquet Will Conclude
Anniversary Program
Tomorrow Night

Stiff Schedule

The fall practice, Captain Robinson explained, is primarily to
develop stickwork. Stickwork has
always carried the Black and Blue
to victory, and it is to stickwork
that Jays owe their fame and reputation. It was also announced
that the team will not play any
lacrosse clubs for two reasons, because the Jays get no credit if
they should down any club, while
on the other hand if some small
club should trounce Hopkins, the
Jays would be hurt considerably
and the club would get quite a
reputation. The Jays will not play
the Alumni for the same reason.
A very difficult schedule has
been outlined for the squad. The
foremost contenders for their
crown will be Army, Navy, Yale
and Maryland. Although Yale
has not a very strong team, it is
quite experienced with all kinds
of stick wielding, and through
this, the Bulldog downed Maryland's strong team several years
ago.

FIFTIETH ANNIVERSARY
CEREMONIES OPENED BY
D.D.K. SMOKER AT DORMS
Fifty Attend Tenth Year
Celebration of
Society

Only thirty men reported at the
organization meeting of the lacrosse team last Monday.. The
poor showing, Captain Robinson
thinks, is due to the fact that there
were other activity meetings on
the same day, and not to any lack
of lacrosse candidates. However
that may be, Robinson urged that
many more men come out, as
there were excellent opportunities
for all who wished to try out.

tearn appeared rather weak, defeating the weak Tank School
eleven in their game by only 7-0;
and then dropping the next two
c

reversal of form, and the Evergreens arrive here tomorrow fresh
from last Saturday's
28-0 victory
over Washington
College.

DR. GOODNOW

PRICE,5 CENTS

President Frank J. Goodnow,
Prominent Figure in Fiftieth
Anniversary Program

RIFLE TEAM COMPLETES
TENTATIVE SCHEDULE
FOR COMING SEASON
Four

Shoulder-to-Shoulder Matches
Scheduled; Torres' Absence
Hurts Team Chances

Celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Johns Hopkins University began last night when Omicron
Delta Kappa, honorary fraternity,
held a smoker at the Alumni Memorial Dormitory. The entertainment, commemorating the tenth anniversary of the society's founding
at Hopkins was attended by about
fifty members. Walter B. Swindell, Jr., acted as toastmaster and
I. EVans Rodgers entertained with
songs and jokes.
A meeting ,at the Lyric Theatre
this 'morning was the first important event of the anniversary program. Dr. Andrew Balfour, Director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Science, was the
principal speaker. Introductory remarks were made by Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland and
Dr. William H. Welch.
Many of the various departments
of the University have planned conferences. for this afternoon and
dinners this evening. The physics
department has arranged a dinner
at the -Baltimore Country Club at
Roland Park, and members of the
class of 1891 will be the guests of
Mr. Alfred J. Shriver, prominent
local lawyer. Members of the biology, political economy and history
departments have also planned special entertainments and meetings
for this afternoon.

With the announcement of a
tentative schedule for the coming
year and the organization of the
rifle club, the rifle team is getting
under way.
The sch'edule . so far includes
twenty-five matches, eleven less
than last year; but this is by no
means complete.
Two new opponents have been
added thus far, Washington College and the formidable Navy
team, that Hopkins will meet
shoulder to shoulder on the same
range.
The weak point in the schedule
is the scarcity of shoulder to
shoulder matches, where the opposing teams meet on a the same
range. Only four have been

"THERE IS NONE SO BLIND"
After months of careful planning, the Half Century Celebration is now at its height. Hundreds of alumni, from all parts
of the country, and many other scholars of note are assembled in
what promises to be one of the most significant gatherings of its
kind ever held. The NEWS-LETTER wishes to add its welcome
to those already more formally expressed.
From a purely Hopkins point of view, the Half Century
Celebration is not only the most important event of the year;
it is the most important in many years, perhaps the greatest since
the inauguration of President Gilman. Viewed in this light, the
apathy which seems to prevail is little short of shocking. It would
be the most natural thing in the world to call this attitude indifference. But to do justice to the undergraduates, and we naturally include ourselves in that term, we do not think that is
the true reason.
The real cause is blindness. No student with any claim to intelligence will deny that the event is important. The trouble is
that it cannot be seen in its true perspective. Twenty years from
now undergraduates, if there be any, will look back on it with
considerable awe and no less regret. At present the everyday
affairs on the campus—sports, publications, and the hysteria of
the open week of fraternity rushing—all claim their share of attention; and leave the Half Century Celebration as an indistinct
unreality, too big to be grasped at once.
The first meeting has already been held; we hope that a fair
number of undergraduates attended. During the remainder of the
time, every student would do well to drop his routine activities,
or even neglect an assignment or two; and attend any phase of
the Celebration which is open to him. If in sonic cases that is
impossible they can read about it.

DISGUST NOT REQUIRED
There is, as anyone who takes the trouble may observe, a
column in the NEWS-LETTER known as the "Mailbag," composed
of letters addressed, as a manner of form and courtesy, to the
editor. Using the numbers of the NEWS-LETTER which have appeared this year as evidence, it would be equally correct to assume
that no one may submit a letter unless he is disgusted at something. The object of his wrath makes no difference: it may
range from the exhorbitant cost of drinking cups to the organization and administration of the whole University.
In this last assertion, however, circumstantial evidence proves
its inadequacy. A sour frame of mind is in no way frowned
upon, but it is by no means essential. We see a future for the
"Mailbag" if it is used sensibly. Since Hopkins is a universit5‘,
itiS safe to assume that there is some intellectual life among the
undergraduates. They must have views on literature, art, or
world affairs; if the views are conflicting, so much the better.
Why not make the letter column a forum as well as a complaint
column ?

are the only letter men that will

year won the marksmanship cup,

and his absence will be keenly
felt. This also necessitates the

The tentative schedule is as follows:
December 4—Princeton, Denison.
December 11—Connecticut Aggies,
West Virginia, Gettysburg.
December 18—Vermont, Syracuse,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
January 8—U. of Porto Rico, North
Carolina State.
- January 15—Western Maryland,
Carnegie Tech.
February 5—Delaware, Washington
College.
February 12—Open, I. R. A.
February 19—I. R. A., Gettysburg
(shoulder match).
February 26-1. R. A., Maryland
(shoulder match).
March 5—I. R. A., Navy (shoulder
match).
March 12—I. R. A., Georgetown
(shoulder match).
March 19—Columbia, Illinois.

FALL LACROSSE PRACTICE
STARTED
(Continuedfrom Page I, Column 3)

good prospects for outhomes.
Liebensperger and Biddison, veteran defense men, are back, with
Mallonee showing some skill at
wing defense. There is a probability that Morrell, a veteran defense man, will play again this
year despite his being a graduate
student. Finn, who displayed remarkable skill in last year's Alumni game, is back again for goal,
with a possibility of Ferlaino's
playing in the non-league games.
Equipment was given out last
Tuesday and practice started the
same day. Robinson did not start
his Jays at strenuous practice the
first day as he did not want them
to get stiff at the beginning of the
fall practice season.

NOTICES
ALUMNUS!
If you want to keep up with
the University undergraduate
happenings, subscribe to the
NEWS-LETTER. It is the official campus publication. Write
to the Circulation Manager!
SOPHOMORES
All members of the sophomore
class are requested to obtain and
read copies of the newly drawnup class constitution from any
member of the Constitution Committee. Those on the committee
are R. Burnett, R. Wood, G. Hershey and S. V. Chapman.
LACROSSE
Lacrosse practice has been
called for Tuesday, Wednesday
and Friday afternoons.
CORRECTION
The correct date of the First
Cotillon, as announced by the
Cotillon Club, will be November
13, instead of November 30. The
News-Letter regrets the error of
its previous announcement.

A SURE FIRE EXTINGUISHER
AND A GOOD INSECTICIDE

Dear Sir:
This is the first time in two and
a half years of residence at Hopkins that I have felt the desire to
write to the NEWS-LETTER. It will
Probably be the last, so I beg you
to publish this humble epistle.
First, I want to state that I have
verY little appreciation of the fine
arts; my education in that line has
been sadly neglected: Second, I do
not care to oppose any efforts on
the part
of the person or persons
who may be trying to beautify the
campus.
But-----my ideas of aesthetics are
very much distorted by the construction
of a cinder path across
the upper quadrangle. I can't understand how a carload of. burnt
coal - enhances the appearance of a
Plot of grass, even though the burnt
coal is arranged in a temporarily
neat way. So much for the aesthetic side.
When the path is completed,- it
will be seldom used. Very few peoPle enjoy walking on them, and to
inY mind for good reasons. The
cinders dirty your shoes, blow in
your eyes, and add to the trouble
of walking. If the path is not run
straight from the West entrance of
the
Chemistry Laboratory to the
flimsy
wooden steps which facilitate one's descent to the level of
the Engineering Buildings, its function as a path will be hopeless.
Most college students have heard
that a straight line is the shortest
distance between two points, and
they always
have this idea in mind
when walking.
May I ask how the work on the
Path has gone
this far (half-way)
fl€1 escaped the notice of your edi- 1
torial
writers? I was very much
disappointed not to find an article
about it in to-day's NEWS-LETTER,
fact, that is why I took my pen
hand, etc. Why not appoint a
ccinunittee and have an investiga
tion? It is quite the thing these
Clays.
Yours very truly,
PETER F. CONROY, JR.
A MORE TIMELY ANSWER
To the
Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.

Dear Sir

Noticing the above, I perceive
that while the writer has lots of
faults to find,
he has few suggestions to give. Investigation has
already begun concerning the unsIghtly cinder path across
the quadrangle
It has been suggested to
the
powers in charge that a little
.-1°neY
1-1
spent on putting down an
inlaid,
flagstone walk would save
the
beautiful appearance of the upPer quadrangle
and likewise serve
as
a practical means of transportation.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 22, 1926

4
FROSH-SOPH DEBATE SET
FOR DECEMBER 2
Dr. French Will Pick Teams on Next
Wednesday and Thursday

"Resolved: That the non-athletic
activities of the American college
constitute an unwise use of the students' time" will be the subject of
the Freshman-Sophomore debate, to
be held at the Assembly, December 2.
Try-outs for the teams of the
respective classes will be held next
Wednesday and Thursday, October
27 and 28, in room 112, Gilman
Hall, at 12:20 P. AI. The frosh
will meet on Wednesday and the
sophs on Thursday.
Each candidate should prepare a
three-minute talk on the above subject. The teams will be chosen by
Dr. French.

Seniors to Meet
Concerning Election

Carl J. Doederlein

As only fifty-five of the one
hundred and twenty-four graduating seniors voted in the recent election a quorum was not obtained. A
meeting will be held Tuesday to
straighten out the question. Either
the constitution will have to
be changed to make the election
valid, or a re-election will be necessary.

°TRAFFIC stopped as big Frank Ket2- cheson,Supt. of Steel Construction for

E keeps them guessing, does the back,
because when he gets the ball he can pass,

Men preparing for industry or commerce can
put themselves in an equally strategic position.
It all gets back to the simple idea of being
broad and versatile.
An engineer should be well up on his specialty,
of course, but he should also keep an open
mind for questions of finance, law and public
relations—if he aspires to a high place in the
councils of his organization.
Such "all-aroundness" typifies in particular
men who have brought the electrical communication industry to what it is today, and
who will carry it to still greater development
in the years to come.
